title: How to Make Simple Crutches

steps.headline: Choose some straight-grained sound lumber suitable for the project.
steps.description: Oak, poplar, ash, or hickory are good, strong, bendable hardwoods, but even a softwood like white pine used in the illustrations will do in a pinch.

steps.headline: Rip the wood to yield two 1 ⁄4 inch (3.2 cm) by 1 ⁄2 inch (3.8 cm) boards about 66 inches (167.6 cm) long.
steps.description: Mark these 12 inches (30.5 cm) from one end and rip them down their centers from the end to the mark so the two limbs can be separated.

steps.headline: Drill a ⁄8 inch (1.0 cm) hole through the center 2 inches (5.1 cm) below the mark at the end of the rip cut in the previous step.
steps.description: Insert a ⁄8 inch (1.0 cm) hex bolt through this hole with a flat washer on the head of the bolt, place another washer on the threaded end, and then install the hex nut, tightening it snugly.

steps.headline: Cut a wedge ⁄4 inch (1.9 cm) wide to a point, 3 inches (7.6 cm) long, and drive it between the two limbs to spread them out.
steps.description: The sides should each bow out symmetrically and form a "Y" shape.

steps.headline: Cut a 1X1 inch block of your wood 4 inches (10.2 cm) long with a 15 degree bevel on each end for each crutch grip, then bore a ⁄8 inch (1.0 cm) hole through the center, lengthwise.
steps.description: Sand or shape these blocks round so they are comfortable to hold.

steps.headline: Mark a center where the grip should fit through the limbs by placing the end of the crutch on the ground and dropping your hand to a comfortable height between the limbs.
steps.description: For an adjustable grip, a series of holes can be drilled so the grip can be raised or lowered for persons who are different heights. For a crutch being used by one person, the single mark you have made is all that needs to be drilled.

steps.headline: Push a 3/8 all-thread rod through one limb, the grip, and then the other limb, place flat washers and then nuts on each end of these bolts.
steps.description: Tighten the nuts securely, and cut off any of the all-thread rod that extends beyond the nuts.

steps.headline: Hold the crutches by the grips in the position you would use the crutches in, and mark the height the limbs need to be trimmed at.
steps.description: Cut the limbs off at these marks.

steps.headline: Cut two more blocks of wood 1 1/2 inches (5.1 cm) square and 7 inches (17.8 cm) long, then notch each end ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) back from the ends and ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) deep to create steps for the limbs to fit into.
steps.description: Glue and nail the ends of the limbs in these notches to form the tops of the crutches.

steps.headline: Sand or smooth any rough surfaces of the crutches for a more comfortable and attractive crutches.

tyn: 6 feet (1.8 m) of 2X4 lumber, straight grained and free of large knots.
Two 2 inch (5.1 cm) long 3/8 hex bolts
Two 6 inch (15.2 cm) long 3/8 all-thread rod
